captions.text:
Little inspires more fear and anxiety
than a medical procedure.

Luckily, most doctors and surgeons are
required to go through great lengths to
master their profession.
But let's face it. Nobody's perfect.

Don Church received a medical
diagnosis that

everybody dreads. He had a tumor. However,
this wasn't a small tumor.

It was a 13 pound tumor located in the
stomach

that had to be removed immediately. So Don
promptly underwent surgery at the
University of Washington Medical Center.

Fortunately, his surgeon was an expert at
removing the tumor.
Not so fortunately, his surgeon was also

upbeat forgetful. Don was sent home
after surgery and experienced severe
abdominal pain; this of course

could be expected after the removal of
such a large tumor,

but more and more time past, the pain
only became worse.

He notified the hospital, but he was
assured that the pain

was normal. But Don knew something
wasn't right.

Some days he would spend curled up on
his bathroom floor sobbing
relentlessly

from the pain. Aside from that, he began to
develop a metallic taste in his mouth.
When he managed to be able to do

any traveling, he would set off metal
detectors at the airport.

He knew something was wrong. These
occurrences months
after his surgery were anything but normal.

So Don went to a family doctor, who
while examining
Don felt an abnormal lump in his abdomen.

X-rays revealed the Don had a 13 inch
long metal retractor

sewed inside his body. The tool is
used to keep a wound opened
during surgery,

and though counting tools after surgery is
typical medical procedure,

the surgeon somehow overlooked one of the
largest

tools of all. Don underwent emergency
surgery to have the metal retractor
removed and suffered no lasting effects.

For his trouble, the hospital paid him
nearly one hundred thousand dollars.

It was revealed that Don was the fourth
instance where a metal retractor was
left inside a patient
at that same hospital.

Jessica Santillan and her family
went through extraordinary lengths

to see that she got adequate medical
care. At such a young age, Jessica was

plagued by a disorder that was killing
her.

Her heart and lungs were on a path to
failure, and no doctor in her home
country of Mexico

could help her. So her family did what any
family would:

they worked to find her the help she
needed to survive

at any cost. Jessica's family actually
managed to smuggle her

into the United States and they took up
residency in a trailer in North
Carolina.

Having no money, Jessica's family
continued to champion for her cause.

They started fundraisers, and raised
enough money to see to it

that Jessica would be able to get a heart
and double lung transplant.

The surgery would be a life-changing one,
even if successful,

but for Jessica and her family it would
become a horrifying ordeal.

Surgeons prepared to work and put Jessica
under anesthesia.

The lung machines and bypass were all
started and the surgeons were ready to
begin.

The surgeon’s expert hands went to work,
and admittedly they worked well.

Jessica's new heart and lungs were
transplanted without an issue.

Her lungs began breathing on their own
and her new heart started beating away.

The surgeon was preparing to close her up
and send her to the ICU.

That's when they received a call from
immunology.

They informed the surgeon the horrific
true. While Jessica had type

O blood, the organs she was given were
type A.

Her body immediately began to dispense
antibodies that started destroying

her new organs, not only wasting
perfectly good organs

but putting Jessica into serious
jeopardy. Doctors did all the could for
Jessica.

They found new compatible organs and
performed a second transplant procedure.

Unfortunately, Jessica slipped into
a coma and suffered severe brain damage,

and died just days later. Her family sued
the hospital for undisclosed amount of

money. Neither the family nor the
hospital
are allowed to talk about the settlement.

Sherman Sizemore, a Baptist minister, began
to experience

unexplained abdominal pain. So he was
scheduled for exploratory surgery.

Sherman was admitted to Raleigh General
Hospital in West Virginia.

To keep Sherman’s muscles from twitching
during the procedure, he was administered
a paralytic drug.

Unable to move, doctors cut him open and
began to search through Sherman's organs,

physically shifting his insides about.
Everything seemed to be going well,

but for Sherman, the procedure was
anything but

well. What the surgeon hadn’t realized was
that Sherman was under the effects of
the paralytic drug,

but he hadn't yet been put under
general anesthesia.

Sherman, while being cut open and searched
through, may have been unable to move
or react.

But he was wholly awake and aware. He
felt every
inch of the incision, every poke and prod,

but there was nothing he could do about
it. After the surgery Sherman's life
changed dramatically.

The experience was so torturous that
it scarred him

physically and mentally. He started to
experience

terrible nightmares and couldn't be left
alone. The hospital

didn't immediately admit to their error,
causing Sherman to struggle with not
knowing if his memories were real
or not. It tormented his every waking

moment. Eventually, he started to become
delusional and believe that people were
trying to bury him alive.

Less than one month later, Sherman shot
himself to death.

Experts estimate that tens of thousands
of patients

experience what is called anaesthetic
awareness each year

during surgery. While these instances may
scare you,

don't worry. You probably won't ever have
this type of experience.

Probably. I'd like to let you all know
that Seriously Strange has its own
Twitter.

Here you can get extra doses of
creepiness about anything from the
bizarre and unexplainable

to serial killers. If you just so happen
to have trouble waiting for a new episode
of Seriously Strange each week,

you can go down into the description
below

and there is a link down there. Be sure to
follow it, you won't regret it.

That's all for now. Remember: you may not
believe it, but anything is possible on
a world so Seriously Strange.

I'm Rob Dyke and I’ll see you next
Wednesday, so don't forget to subscribe

because you won't want to miss what's
next.

I haven't had any surgical errors, but once at the dentist I was getting a 
tooth removed (I was about 8 or 9) and they injected me with that numbing 
medicine. Only, the dentist went on her lunch break, forgetting she had a 
patient. By the time she came back the medicine had worn off and I felt 
them pull my tooth out. Every second of it. I was screaming to them that I 
could feel it, but the stupid nurse just said "it doesn't hurt."﻿

comments.author: Jrock69 Music Club

comments.text:
My Granddad went to hospital after having pains abdominal pains. The pains 
weren't that bad. After a few days he decided to get checked out. He had an 
X-ray done and found out it look like a mass in his intestines. He went 
into surgery and opened up his bowels there was nothing there. Stitched him 
back up. He was fine. For a few days laughing and joking no pain. Then 
after a few days he became very ill severe pain and he collapsed. A few 
hours later he was dead. Caused of death blood poisoning. Surgeons forgot 
to stitch up his bowel properly. One week later one of the surgeons went on 
holiday. If my grandad didn't go to hospital or didn't have the surgery he 
would still be alive today there was nothing wrong with him. ﻿

That surgeon, the one from the heart and lung case. yeah, that was MY 
FATHER... I am happy with the way Rob depicted this incident. My dad 
received blame and ridicule from the press for this surgery, but in 
reality, there was nothing he could do. He is an incredibly talented 
surgeon, and I am extremely proud of him. His thoughts are still with that 
family to this day.﻿

comments.author: SkylerCloudie

comments.text:
If you're worried about anaesthetic awareness, most of it is incredibly 
mild - you wake up for a few seconds without pain, the doctors notice and 
give you another dose, you konk back out and don't even remember it 
happening. The case discussed here is a very rare but very serious case of 
post-traumatic stress disorder that can occur in extreme cases of 
anaesthetic awareness.﻿

I had a brief brush with anesthesia awareness when I was fourteen. After 
being put under for surgery, I had a nightmare that I was being stabbed in 
the throat. The pain was awful and I felt on the verge of gagging, but was 
unable to do so. When I woke up, the pain in my throat was still there. My 
parents and I later realized that I had felt the doctors putting the 
breathing tube down my throat.﻿

comments.text:
I myself have experienced a form of anesthetic awareness, thankfully very 
different from the one listed, when i was young, i had eye trouble, weak 
muscles in my eye sockets causing them to drift, a simple surgery fixed 
that with one little problem, my body, even though young, was very 
resistant to the drug, and i woke up in the middle of surgery and saw the 
doctors stitching my eye, though thankfully it was completely painless, 
they realized i was awake, stopped to give me more medication, and the rest 
of the surgery was a success with no further problems, it did scare me a 
little, the anxiety of seeing a needle so close to my eye, but i quickly 
got over it﻿

comments.text:
After i've been bitten in the face by a dog i went under 
emergency-surgery... I dont know why, either there was too much adrenalin 
pumping through my vains or the anethestic drug dose was too weak, but i 
woke up while in surgery.. I felt all of it every time the needle was put 
through my skin I felt it every time it came near my face I saw it... Well 
even the most painkillers dont work on me neither... It was scary and I had 
many nightmares.. But knowing that my body reacts like that I'm still 
scared when it comes to surgeries but I learned to live with it. ﻿
